posts.name: Marwan Rahman
posts.cooked:
Hey all! My team wants to use a servo motor to activate a hinge to move a small metal plate. I was thinking of using a coprocessor (raspberry pi) to control said servo with an external power supply and an Adafruit Motor HAT. Is there any better/simpler solution? It would be convenient to use said raspberry pi as we’d like to use vision processing.

The motor we’re using for now is the VEX 3-wire servo.
Plug the servo into one the Rio’s PWM ports

posts.name: Marwan Rahman
posts.cooked: is that it? would the roborio give it power and also would we be able to actually control it or would it be continuous.

marwanrahman23:

is that it?

yes

marwanrahman23:

would the roborio give it power and also would we be able to actually control it

yes

posts.name: Marwan Rahman
posts.cooked: thanks! didn’t know it was that simple.

posts.name: jhajel
posts.cooked: If you need more power than RoboRio can provide you can get one of these:

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
marwanrahman23:

control said servo with an external power supply and an Adafruit Motor HAT

You should read the robot construction rules fully, specifically R506 and R712. The configuration you are proposing is illegal if I understand your post correctly. The servo must be controlled by a PWM port on the roborio and it must be powered by the RoboRIO, a Servo Power Module, or a WCP Spartan sensor board (not sold anymore).

If it’s a light duty servo, powering off the roborio should be fine. I believe it handles up to 2.2A of current (total across all pins). If it’s heavy duty, you should use a Servo Power Module.
